title: Basic Bangla
details: Ates back to the 7th century at least and it may be divided into three main periods: ancient, medieval, and modern. The different periods may be dated as follows: ancient period from 650-1200, medieval period from 1200-1800, and the modern period from 1800 to the present. The medieval period may again be divided into three periods: early medieval also known as the period of transition from 1200-1350; high medieval from 1350-1700, including the pre-Chaitanya period from 1350-1500 and the Chaitanya period from 1500-1700; and late medieval from 1700-1800. The modern period begins in 1800 and can again be divided into six phases: the era of prose from 1800-1860, the era of development from 1860-1900, the phase of rabindranath tagore 1861-1941 from 1890-1930, the post-Rabindranath phase from 1930 to 1947, the post-partition phase from 1947 to 1970, and the Bangladesh phase from 1971 to the present.

title: School Math
details: Although finding good math materials on the Internet might be difficult, there are countless outstanding resources available, including blogs that provide informative explanations, practice problems with step-by-step directions, and more.  So, to spare you time in your search, we've filtered the entire internet with this list of our favorite mathematics blog websites. Whether you’re a student looking to learn more about mathematics or a professional looking to keep up with the latest techniques and trends, you’ll enjoy the blogs on our list. Happy reading! Math With Bad Drawings is one of the top math blogs to follow. This blog, written and drawn by math teacher Ben Orlin, uses stick figures and humorous text to explain math concepts. The drawings catch everyone's attention. It's incredible how he uses the drawing as a metaphor for so many things. It isn't overly technical, but it does cover a wide range of mathematics-related topics, such as math education, math culture, current events in the math world, math humor, and so on.

title: Advanced Bangla literature
details: Aryan languages became widely spoken in the Bengal delta as a result of the Mauryas' invasion of Bengal in the third century BC. But the bangla language emerged from prakrit without any direct input from Aryan languages, via apabhramsa and abahattha. The 47 Buddhist monks' spiritual poems known as charyapada are the earliest examples of ancient Bangla still in existence. The language used in these hymns is known as sandhya, or twilight language, due to its limited comprehension. The hymns of Charyapada are valuable in terms of language and literature. The authors of the Charyapada hymns are known as the Siddhacharya, and they are Luipa, Bhusukupa, Kahnapa, and Savarpa.

title: English for kids
details: Passion makes learning fun and a lot easier. if your teacher has a passion for english then your are in for good time. english with a twist is a grat english learning. we relishes the opportunity to share her knowledge enthusiasm for the english learning.Phrase Mix is a wonderful site that fully examines English phrases. It provides explanations of what they mean and the contexts in which they are used.The average posts are fairly short at around 200-300 words. All are packed with great information that is neatly presented on the page.Learn English and have a good laugh at the same time. Or, “split your sides laughing,” to use an English idiom. This unconventional blog for learning English presents a series of jokes and then explains why they are funny. This is a novel approach to language learning that also helps the student learn more about English culture. There are plenty of idiomatic expressions along with the laugh out loud moments.

title: Physics Advanced
details: Jeremy Kuns blog is about The junction of Math and Programming, which is represented by the symbol in the name, for those who are not familiar with it. Jeremy Kun is a Google employee with a strong background in computer science and a drive to solve coding issues. As a result of Kun's passion with discovering mathematical solutions to programming difficulties, he founded the website Math Programming. His collection of articles is sizable and at least novel-length. Kun's Math Programming is the ideal blog for you if you're seeking for a comprehensive approach to computer science's mathematical foundations. Dr. Tanya Khovanova oversees this outstanding blog, which is brimming with rare Math material. She is a Mathletics coach at the Advanced Math and Sciences and a free-lance mathematician.

title: Advanced chemistry
details: One of the most modern chemistry blogs on this list that will appeal to students and young professionals on their way to joining the chemistry community. Blogger Mariam Zaki has a degree in Medicinal Chemistry and translates every new blog post into Arabic to help share her chemistry blogging to a more diverse audience. Her topics include science communication, science policy in government, chemistry as it applies to every-day health decisions and news from the chemistry community. Mariam’s blog is easy to read and written in a conversational tone, plus it’s still very active as of November 2019. Make sure to follow her active social media accounts below! In this blog dating back to 2013, chemist Dr. Kat Day (@chronicleflask on Twitter, Facebook) takes on popular trends and news headlines that are either using questionable science claims or sensationalizing good science. She does a great job going after relevant topics to the every-day reader including super-slippery toilet coatings, reusing water bottles and homeopathic consumer products. Her amusing and skeptical tone makes it easy to read and will keep you clicking backwards through the archives to catch up!

title: Learn Arts
details: Arts|Learning is the hub of arts education in Massachusetts. We support the inclusion of a complete arts education (dance, media arts, music, drama/theatre, and visual arts) for every K-12 student in the Commonwealth. When the arts are at the center of the core curriculum, students develop the 21st-Century skills they need to lead fulfilled lives. As a non-profit organization, A|L is the Massachusetts arts education alliance partnering with dozens of professional arts education organizations, cultural institutions, and public agencies to bring about changes in the way the arts are viewed and supported within public education. We bring years of experience and acknowledged expertise to bear on arts education, programming, services, professional development for educators, and advocacy.

title: DU Bangla
details: The Bengal delta saw the spread of Aryan languages as a result of the Mauryas' invasion of Bengal in the third century BC. The bangla language, on the other hand, emerged from prakrit, outside of the direct impact of Aryan languages, via apabhramsa and abahattha. The 47 spiritual hymns known as charyapada, which were written by Buddhist monks, are the earliest examples of ancient Bangla still in existence. The language used in these hymns is referred to as sandhya, or twilight language, because it is only partially intelligible. Both linguistic and literary significance can be found in the Charyapada hymns. Luipa, Bhusukupa, Kahnapa, and Savarpa are some of the Siddhacharya, or authors, of the Charyapada hymns.

title: JU Bangla
details: Aryan languages spread over the Bengal delta after the Mauryas' conquest of Bengal in the third century BC. However, without being directly influenced by Aryan languages, the bangla language evolved from prakrit through apabhramsa and abahattha. The 47 Buddhist monk-written spiritual hymns collectively referred to as charyapada are the earliest examples of ancient Bangla still in existence. It is known as sandhya, or twilight language, because the language used in these hymns is only partially understandable. Language- and literature-wise, the Charyapada hymns are valuable. Luipa, Bhusukupa, Kahnapa, and Savarpa are known as the Siddhacharya, or hymns of Charyapada composers.
